critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their white tail as a warning signal to alert others of danger nearby.
critters.activeFact: White-tailed deer have a four-chambered stomach that helps them digest tough plants like leaves and twigs.
factHistory: White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds.
critters.activeFact: Black bears can climb trees quickly, especially when they‚Äôre young, to escape danger or reach food.
factHistory: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food sources for years!
Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, nearly seven times better than a bloodhound.
Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to various habitats, from deserts to urban areas, showing impressive survival skills.
critters.activeFact: Coyotes can adjust their hunting style based on what‚Äôs available, switching from mice to fruit to deer carrion as needed.
factHistory: Coyotes are highly adaptable and can live in deserts, forests, mountains, and even cities!
Coyotes use high-pitched yips and howls to communicate and coordinate with their pack during hunts.
Coyotes can adapt to diverse habitats, including urban areas, making them highly versatile survivors.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm in cold weather.
critters.activeFact: Red foxes have vertical-slit pupils that help them judge distance when pouncing on prey.
factHistory: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm during cold weather.
Red foxes have excellent hearing, able to detect small animals digging underground.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes can climb trees to escape predators, unlike most other North American fox species.
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes can climb by using strong, hooked claws, and they often rest on low branches to stay safe.
factHistory: Gray foxes can climb trees, an unusual skill for members of the dog family!
Gray foxes are unique canids that can climb trees to escape predators and find food.
Gray foxes are one of the few canids that can climb trees to escape predators.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have excellent night vision, allowing them to hunt effectively in low-light conditions.
critters.activeFact: Bobcats use scent marking and scratch posts to define territory and communicate with other bobcats.
factHistory: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, helping them catch prey and climb trees quickly!
Bobcats have excellent night vision, aiding their hunting during nighttime or low-light conditions.
Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, making them excellent climbers and hunters.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines cannot shoot quills; quills detach easily when touched by predators or threats.
critters.activeFact: Porcupines are strong climbers and often spend time in trees feeding on bark and buds.
factHistory: Porcupines have thousands of sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.
Porcupines' quills detach easily to deter predators, acting as a unique and effective natural defense.
Porcupines have up to 30,000 sharp quills for defense, which they cannot shoot but easily detach.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using branches, mud, and stones to create ponds for protection against predators.
critters.activeFact: Beavers have orange front teeth because the enamel is iron-rich and built for chewing wood.
factHistory: Beavers build dams to create ponds, helping protect their homes from predators and harsh weather.
Beavers build dams using branches, mud, and rocks to create aquatic habitats for protection and food storage.
Beavers have transparent eyelids that allow them to see underwater while swimming.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges using vegetation and mud, providing shelter from predators and weather.
critters.activeFact: Muskrat lodges often have underwater entrances, helping them avoid predators on the surface.
factHistory: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, similar to beavers, but much smaller and cozier!
Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, which protect them from predators and harsh weather.
Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, often with underwater entrances for protection against predators.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are excellent swimmers and use their webbed feet to hunt fish and aquatic animals efficiently.
critters.activeFact: Minks have dense, water-resistant fur that helps them stay warm while hunting along icy shorelines.
factHistory: Minks have waterproof fur, helping them stay dry and warm while swimming underwater for food!
Minks are excellent swimmers, using partially webbed feet to hunt fish and amphibians underwater.
Minks are semi-aquatic mammals skilled at swimming and hunting fish, small mammals, and birds.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and use trees to escape predators and hunt prey.
critters.activeFact: Fishers are one of the few predators that can successfully hunt porcupines by targeting the face and flipping them.
factHistory: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even chase prey up trees!
Fishers are skilled climbers and use their agility to hunt prey like squirrels and birds.
Fishers are skilled climbers and use tree cavities for shelter and raising their young.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to prevent water from entering while swimming.
critters.activeFact: River otters have dense, water-repellent fur that traps air and keeps them insulated in cold water.
factHistory: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to eight minutes while hunting fish.
River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to stay submerged while hunting.
River otters have dense, water-repellent fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming.

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find nuts buried beneath a foot of snow using memory and scent.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Gray Squirrels sometimes ‚Äúfake-bury‚Äù food to trick other squirrels watching them.
factHistory: Eastern Gray Squirrels can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst!
Eastern Gray Squirrels use their bushy tails for balance, communication, and warmth in cold weather.
Eastern Gray Squirrels can find food buried beneath a foot of snow using memory and smell.

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches from intruders year-round.
critters.activeFact: Red squirrels build ‚Äúmiddens,‚Äù large cone-scale piles that serve as long-term food storage sites.
factHistory: American Red Squirrels defend territories year-round, storing food in scattered caches called middens.
American Red Squirrels are fierce defenders of their food caches, aggressively protecting them from intruders.
American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches from intruders year-round.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches to carry food back to their burrows for storage.
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks sort and store food in separate chambers underground, helping keep seeds drier and longer-lasting.
factHistory: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows for storage.
Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows.
Chipmunks have cheek pouches that expand to carry food back to their burrows efficiently.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally to blend into snow or forest floor for camouflage.
critters.activeFact: Snowshoe hares have large, fur-covered feet that spread their weight like natural snowshoes.
factHistory: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.
Snowshoe Hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Cottontails often rely on freezing still to avoid detection before bolting in a zigzag sprint.
factHistory: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!
Eastern Cottontails use their strong hind legs to make quick, zigzag escapes from predators.
Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have exceptionally nimble front paws, allowing them to open jars and manipulate objects skillfully.
critters.activeFact: Raccoons can rotate their hind feet to climb down trees headfirst, giving them great control on trunks.
factHistory: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them identify objects by touch, even underwater!
Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that can remember how to open containers and solve puzzles.
Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws, allowing them to open containers and solve complex tasks.

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to many snake venoms, including rattlesnake and cottonmouth venom.
critters.activeFact: When threatened, opossums may hiss and bare teeth first, and only then resort to ‚Äúplaying dead.‚Äù
factHistory: Opossums play dead to avoid predators, slowing their heartbeat and breathing to appear lifeless.
Opossums have a remarkable immune system that makes them resistant to many snake venoms.
Opossums are the only North American marsupials, carrying and nursing their babies in a pouch.

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators.
critters.activeFact: Skunks usually warn first by stomping their feet and raising their tail before spraying.
factHistory: Striped skunks can accurately spray their smelly liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators!
Striped skunks can spray a powerful, foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.
Striped skunks can accurately spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide up to 150 feet using a flap of skin called a patagium between their limbs.
critters.activeFact: Flying squirrels steer during glides using their tail like a rudder and can land with impressive accuracy.
factHistory: Flying squirrels glide by spreading a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.
Flying squirrels glide up to 150 feet using a flap of skin between their legs called a patagium.
Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium stretched between their limbs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and hunt insects in complete darkness.
critters.activeFact: Little Brown Bats can enter torpor to conserve energy, slowing their metabolism during cold periods.
factHistory: Little Brown Bats can eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes in an hour‚Äînature‚Äôs own nighttime pest control!
Little Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and catch insects in complete darkness.
Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-air with incredible precision and speed.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats eat hundreds of insects each night, helping control pest populations naturally.
critters.activeFact: Big Brown Bats often roost in buildings and can survive cold snaps by using short torpor cycles.
factHistory: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control mosquito populations naturally at night!
Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, consuming up to half their body weight nightly.
Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, consuming thousands each night.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like, ‚ÄúWho cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?‚Äù
critters.activeFact: Barred Owls have feather edges that muffle sound, letting them fly quietly while hunting.
factHistory: Barred Owls can mimic the calls of other birds to confuse their prey or rivals.
Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"
Barred Owls have distinctive hooting calls that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have fierce talons nicknamed "death talons" for their powerful hunting grip.
critters.activeFact: Great Horned Owls often start nesting in late winter, sometimes using old hawk or crow nests.
factHistory: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow!
Great Horned Owls have powerful talons that can crush prey bones, making them top nighttime hunters.
Great Horned Owls have ear tufts that help with camouflage and communication, not actual ears.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds from feeders.
critters.activeFact: Blue Jays are known to cache food in multiple spots and revisit those stashes later.
factHistory: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.
Blue Jays can mimic the calls of hawks to scare away other birds from their territory.
Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds from feeders and territories.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Male Northern Cardinals sing to defend territory and attract mates, creating bright, clear melodies.
critters.activeFact: Northern Cardinals don‚Äôt migrate, so the same birds can visit feeders year-round.
factHistory: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where both males and females sing beautifully.
Male Northern Cardinals sing to defend territory and attract mates, making their bright red plumage even more eye-catching.
Northern Cardinals are one of the few songbirds where males and females sing different songs.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout winter.
critters.activeFact: Black-capped Chickadees can lower their body temperature overnight to conserve energy in cold weather.
factHistory: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the winter.
Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food during winter.
Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout winter.

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use a variety of calls, including a distinctive ‚Äúpeter-peter-peter‚Äù whistle to communicate.
critters.activeFact: Tufted Titmice often carry a single seed away to crack it open on a branch before eating.
factHistory: Tufted Titmice use their strong feet to cling upside down while searching for insects on tree bark!
Tufted Titmice can mimic the calls of other birds to communicate or defend their territory.
Tufted Titmice often cache seeds to eat later, showing impressive memory skills in the wild.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only climb upwards.
critters.activeFact: Nuthatches sometimes wedge seeds into bark cracks and hammer them open like a tiny forest locksmith.
factHistory: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike many other birds!
White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most other birds.
White-breasted Nuthatches often climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that go upward only.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their stiff tail feathers to brace against tree trunks while pecking for insects.
critters.activeFact: Downy Woodpeckers use stiff tail feathers like a brace to stabilize themselves while climbing and pecking.
factHistory: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, about the size of a sparrow!
Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and find insects hidden beneath the bark.
Downy Woodpeckers use their stiff tail feathers to brace themselves on tree trunks while pecking.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and establish territory, using their strong beaks on trees.
critters.activeFact: Hairy Woodpeckers have a longer bill than downies, letting them reach deeper insects under bark.
factHistory: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects, not just to communicate with other woodpeckers!
Hairy Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and find insects hidden under tree bark.
Hairy Woodpeckers drum rapidly to communicate and establish territory in North American forests.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes to find ants and insects in decaying trees.
critters.activeFact: Pileated Woodpeckers leave large cavities that can later be used by owls, ducks, and other wildlife.
factHistory: Pileated Woodpeckers can drill holes 3 inches wide to find insects hiding deep in trees!
Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.
Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers can cling upside down on tree trunks while searching for insects and sap.
critters.activeFact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers often stash food in bark cracks and return later, especially in winter.
factHistory: Red-bellied Woodpeckers have a strong, chisel-like beak to drill into tree bark for insects.
Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and mark their territory.
Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and establish territory in their woodland habitats.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves are known for their soft, mournful cooing sounds that can carry over long distances.
critters.activeFact: Mourning Doves make a soft whistling sound in flight caused by air rushing through their wing feathers.
factHistory: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them surprisingly fast fliers!
Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour to evade predators.
Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour to escape predators and migrate long distances.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to dull olive in winter.
critters.activeFact: Goldfinches are late nesters and often wait until mid-summer when thistle fluff is available for nests.
factHistory: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to duller feathers in winter!
American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, changing bright yellow feathers in summer to duller olive winter plumage.
American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, changing their bright yellow feathers to olive-brown in winter.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear in northern areas only during winter.
critters.activeFact: Juncos often feed by hopping backward and scratching forward with both feet to uncover seeds.
factHistory: Dark-eyed Juncos change feather colors seasonally, showing brighter plumage during breeding for attracting mates!
Dark-eyed Juncos change plumage color seasonally, appearing brighter in winter for better camouflage in snow.
Dark-eyed Juncos change their song patterns regionally, creating unique local bird dialects across North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are known for their cheerful, warbling songs primarily sung by males to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Male House Finches get their red color from pigments in food, so diet can affect how bright they look.
factHistory: House Finches have red feathers on their heads, which actually come from pigments in the foods they eat!
House Finches are native to the western U.S. but now thrive across much of North America.
House Finches are known for their cheerful, warbling songs used to attract mates and defend territory.

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches have a sweet, warbling song that sounds like a robin with a raspier voice.
critters.activeFact: Purple Finches have strong bills for cracking seeds and often favor conifers and mixed woodlands.
factHistory: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodious songs that help them attract mates and mark their territory.
Purple Finches have a distinctive raspberry red plumage that helps males attract mates during breeding season.
Purple Finches have a raspberry-red head and chest, making them easy to spot in North American forests.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 25 miles per hour and fly short distances at speeds up to 55 mph.
critters.activeFact: Wild turkeys roost in trees at night, even in winter, to avoid ground predators.
factHistory: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 miles per hour for short bursts!
Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds up to 55 miles per hour.
Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances at 55 miles per hour.

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by rapidly beating their wings to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Ruffed Grouse can burrow into soft snow to form a warm snow-roost during cold winter nights.
factHistory: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating their wing feathers to attract mates and mark territory.
Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating air with their wings to attract mates.
Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating air with their wings to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform elaborate courtship dances that include bowing, jumping, and wing-flapping to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Sandhill Cranes have a loud, rolling bugle call that can carry long distances across open wetlands.
factHistory: Sandhill Cranes perform graceful, synchronized dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.
Sandhill Cranes perform synchronized dancing to strengthen pair bonds.
Sandhill Cranes perform intricate group dances involving bowing, jumping, and wing-flapping to communicate and bond.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember them for years, showing advanced problem-solving skills.
critters.activeFact: Crows can gather in groups to mob hawks and owls, working together to drive predators away.
factHistory: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if someone is a threat for years.
American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if a person is threatening or friendly.
American Crows can recognize human faces and remember those who pose threats.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.
critters.activeFact: Ravens can mimic many sounds, including animal calls and human-like noises, to communicate and play.
factHistory: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech and animal calls, showing impressive intelligence.
Common Ravens can mimic human speech and other sounds in their environment with surprising accuracy.
Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks use their keen eyesight to spot prey from over a mile away while soaring high.
critters.activeFact: Red-tailed Hawks often perch on high branches or poles, scanning open ground for small mammals.
factHistory: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their incredible eyesight!
Red-tailed Hawks use their keen eyesight to spot prey from over a mile away during flight.
Red-tailed Hawks use their sharp vision to spot prey from over a mile away.

critters.name: Cooper‚Äôs Hawk
critters.fact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile hunters, easily maneuvering through tight trees to catch small birds and mammals.
critters.activeFact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks have long tails that act like a rudder, helping them steer through trees at high speed.
factHistory: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are skilled flyers that use surprise attacks to catch birds mid-air.
Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile fliers, using quick twists to catch birds mid-air in dense forests.
Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile hunters, known for dashing through dense trees to catch small birds mid-flight.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are the most common wild ducks in North America and easily recognized by their bright green heads.
critters.activeFact: Mallards often feed by dabbling, tipping forward with their tails up while straining plants and insects.
factHistory: Mallard ducks can recognize and remember individual human faces for years.
Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators.
Mallard ducks are known for their distinctive green heads and loud quacking calls during mating season.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and have colorful, iridescent feathers unique among North American waterfowl.
critters.activeFact: Wood Duck ducklings can jump from nest cavities shortly after hatching and usually tumble down safely.
factHistory: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities, making them unique among North American waterfowl species.
Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and are one of the most colorful North American waterfowl species.
Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and their ducklings can jump from great heights safely after hatching.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly over 1,500 miles during migration without stopping to rest.
critters.activeFact: Canada Geese rotate leaders in a V-formation to share the effort of flying into the wind.
factHistory: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, often forming a distinctive V-shaped flying pattern.
Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using strong, graceful V-shaped formations.
Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using a distinctive V-formation to conserve energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can live up to 15 years in the wild and have a wingspan over six feet.
critters.activeFact: Great Blue Herons fly with their necks pulled in, unlike cranes that fly with necks extended.
factHistory: Great Blue Herons can fly at speeds up to 30 miles per hour while hunting for fish.
Great Blue Herons use their long necks like a spear to catch fish with lightning-fast strikes.
Great Blue Herons use their sharp beaks to spear fish with lightning-fast precision.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
critters.activeFact: Painted turtles can slow their metabolism dramatically in cold water, allowing them to overwinter at pond bottoms.
factHistory: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
Painted turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, allowing extended dives.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws strong enough to snap through turtle shells and small bones.
critters.activeFact: Snapping turtles often rely on camouflage and stillness in water, looking like a rock until they strike.
factHistory: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than a second to catch prey!
Snapping turtles have powerful jaws strong enough to snap small bones and catch fish quickly.
Snapping turtles have powerful jaws that can snap shut with incredible force to catch prey.

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can recognize individual humans and remember them, showing impressive fish intelligence.
critters.activeFact: Male bluegills fan out nests in colonies, creating circular ‚Äúbeds‚Äù that can be visible in shallow water.
factHistory: Bluegill fish can hear sounds up to 1,600 Hz, helping them detect predators quickly underwater!
Bluegill can breathe air by gulping surface air when oxygen levels in water are low.
Bluegill can breathe air through their skin in low-oxygen water conditions.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can expand their jaws to swallow prey nearly half their body size whole.
critters.activeFact: Largemouth bass are ambush hunters that often hide near weeds, logs, or rocks before striking suddenly.
factHistory: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!
Largemouth bass can expand their jaws to swallow prey over half their own body length.
Largemouth bass can grow over 20 pounds and have a distinctive jaw that extends past their eyes.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have distinct vertical stripes, making them easy to identify among freshwater fish.
critters.activeFact: Yellow perch often school together, which helps them find food and reduces the risk to any one fish.
factHistory: Yellow Perch have vibrant yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater!
Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater.
Yellow Perch have distinct vertical stripes that help them blend into underwater vegetation.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can ambush prey with explosive bursts of speed underwater.
critters.activeFact: Northern pike have backward-pointing teeth that help keep slippery fish from escaping once caught.
factHistory: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and use sharp teeth to catch their prey swiftly!
Northern Pike use ambush tactics, staying still before quickly striking prey with sharp teeth.
Northern Pike have sharp teeth and ambush prey using quick bursts of speed.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers can be heard singing loudly at night during early spring to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Spring peepers have sticky toe pads that help them climb vegetation around wetlands and ponds.
factHistory: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.
Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched peeping calls during early spring nights.
Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls that signal the start of spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow over 8 inches long, making them one of the largest frog species in North America.
critters.activeFact: Bullfrogs are sit-and-wait hunters and will eat insects, small fish, and other small animals they can catch.
factHistory: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!
American Bullfrogs can produce deep, loud calls that travel over half a mile to attract mates.
American Bullfrogs can produce deep, loud croaks that carry over long distances to attract mates.

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green Frogs can be identified by the distinct ridge running from their eyes down their back.
critters.activeFact: Green frogs often sit at the water‚Äôs edge and dive quickly when threatened, using the pond as instant cover.
factHistory: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!
Green frogs can produce a distinctive, banjo-like call heard during warm, rainy nights.
Green Frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to catch prey or escape predators.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 10 times their body length in a single leap.
critters.activeFact: Leopard frogs are powerful jumpers and can cover surprising distance in a few rapid leaps across wet ground.
factHistory: Leopard frogs get their name from their distinctive dark spots that look like a leopard‚Äôs coat.
Leopard frogs have distinctive dark spots and are excellent jumpers, often leaping over 3 feet in a single bound.
Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes are one of the few snakes that can survive underwater for up to 30 minutes.
critters.activeFact: Garter snakes give live birth rather than laying eggs, with young typically born in late summer.
factHistory: Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians in water, making them excellent swimmers!
Garter snakes can detect chemicals in the environment using their forked tongues and Jacobson‚Äôs organ.
Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians and fish in water.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to an hour while hunting or avoiding predators.
critters.activeFact: Water snakes often bask near shorelines to warm up between swims, helping them stay fast and active.
factHistory: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to two hours while hunting or hiding from predators!
Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 20 minutes while hunting or hiding.
Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful patterns to deter predators.
critters.activeFact: Milk snakes help control rodent populations, which is why they‚Äôre sometimes found near barns and woodpiles.
factHistory: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with similar coloring to avoid predators.
Eastern Milk Snakes vibrate their tails like rattlesnakes to mimic dangerous snakes and avoid predators.
Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful patterns to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to central Mexico for winter.
critters.activeFact: Monarch caterpillars eat milkweed and store its toxins, making many predators avoid them later as butterflies.
factHistory: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to Mexico each fall, one of nature‚Äôs greatest journeys!
Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles between Canada and Mexico each year.
Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from North America to central Mexico each year.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies often mimic bird droppings as caterpillars for camouflage and defense from predators.
critters.activeFact: Some swallowtail caterpillars can extend a forked, smelly organ to scare off predators.
factHistory: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and avoid attacks.
Swallowtail butterflies flutter with distinctive tail-like wing extensions that mimic bird feathers for protection.
Swallowtail butterflies use their tail-like wing extensions to confuse predators during flight.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions, including backward, making them agile aerial hunters.
critters.activeFact: Dragonflies have huge compound eyes that give them near-360-degree vision for tracking prey midair.
factHistory: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, left, and right!
Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects.
Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects in the world.

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their body when resting, unlike dragonflies that hold them open.
critters.activeFact: Damselfly young live underwater, so adults are often found near ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams.
factHistory: Damselflies fold their wings back when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.
Damselflies fold their wings along their body when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep them open.
Damselflies fold their wings neatly over their bodies when at rest, unlike dragonflies.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescent light to attract mates and communicate with each other in the dark.
critters.activeFact: Different firefly species have different flash patterns, like a glowing code for finding the right mate.
factHistory: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, creating magical glowing light shows in warm summer nights!
Fireflies use bioluminescent light to attract mates and communicate in the dark.
Fireflies use bioluminescence to communicate, especially for mating signals during warm summer nights.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.
critters.activeFact: Honeybees can warm the hive by vibrating their flight muscles, helping keep brood at a steady temperature.
factHistory: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of tasty flowers with their hive friends!
Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.
Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of food sources with their hive mates.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature, allowing them to fly in cooler weather than many other bees.
critters.activeFact: Bumblebees can ‚Äúbuzz pollinate,‚Äù vibrating flowers to shake loose extra pollen.
factHistory: Bumblebees can fly despite their small wings by beating them about 200 times per second!
Bumblebees have hairy bodies that help them collect and transfer pollen between flowers efficiently.
Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature to fly in cold weather unlike most other bees.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that allow them to jump over 20 times their body length.
critters.activeFact: Grasshoppers make chirping sounds by rubbing legs against wings, a process called stridulation.
factHistory: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that can leap over 20 times their body length in a single jump!
Grasshoppers can leap over 20 times their own body length in a single jump.
Grasshoppers can leap up to 20 times their body length using powerful hind legs.
